arch:property.oc:show_val: low density scatter or pebbles, stones, sherds and lithics. white plaster with a few flat lying sherds and stones. plaster is poorly preserved, although there is a distinct gray color on this side of the wall. the locus began very small but eventually grew to cover muich of the northern half of the trench (except L127 and L128). presence questionable in L111. seems to extend into the NW baulk. possibly the interior surface of wall L114/116 (now thought to be exterior 6/22). white organic residue of mat impression found near L121 location. 354 L of soil sifted (3 L soil sample), including 9 L HAP sample. see final trench summary
same as L121. needed two loci until the two sections joined.
small stones (10 cm), small to medium pebbles (2-4 cm), pseudomorphs and plaster

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: plaster (poorly preserved), scattered pebbles, sherds, lithics and worked stones in a sandy matrix, with organic residue from a mat impression
unsorted sand and pebble mixture, domestic activity, suprasoil of L134
